issue.title: Add SPDX-License-Identifier headers
issue.body:
Fixes #642.

Before merging:

- [ ] Update [coding conventions wiki page](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/wiki/Coding-conventions)

comment.body:
> Should we mark all of the external files with their respective license, if not, why not? 

I think of 'external' and 'pqclean' files as being added to our repo without being touched by human hands, and I don't want to have to modify all of those files and make them inconsistent with upstream changes.  That's certainly the case for pqclean.  If you think external should be handled differently, let me know.

> What's the purpose of this feature: to facilitate exclusion of files you can't integrate with (if so, can/will our build system be able to facilitate that?)

The purpose of doing this is to very clearly document the license in every file.  I added a unit test that checks that every .c, .h, .s, .S, .py, and various CMake files all have SPDX headers, except for files in the pqclean and external directories.  However, it does not check what license is present, just that the header is present (i.e., it is not automatically checking that no incompatibly licensed files are added); that will still be manual.

> I'd like to see the proposed [coding conventions](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/wiki/Coding-conventions) update before finishing this review.

I've added it to https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/wiki/Coding-conventions and https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/wiki/Contributing-guide.

issue.title: Check algorithm datasheets
issue.body:
Before the release we should check the algorithm datasheets to make sure they are up to date.  Before doing that, we should identify which things merit manual checking.  We don't have a specification of what things should be present in the file.  So I'm looking for some discussion in this issue about what to include.

- What is the difference between 'source of implementation' and 'implementation version' -- do we need both or is one sufficient?
- Check that the license is indeed correct.
- Probably don't need a language field, everything is C or C + assembly.
- 'Architectures supported in liboqs master branch' should be updated:
  - The language 'liboqs master branch' is old (to back when we also had nist-branch) and should be removed
  - This should be where we report what types of optimizations etc can be built (avx2, bmi, etc.).  What is the best way to word and structure that?

Seeking feedback from @baentsch @christianpaquin @xvzcf @vsoftco

comment.body:
I must admit I at first was at a loss where the above-mentioned "algorithm data sheets" can be found: Didn't find them either in Wiki pages nor README... But then... `docs`! Never ran `gen_docs` either :-)

May I thus suggest a (more prominent) link to them, maybe from the License section? And/or the [Algorithms supported](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs#supported-algorithms section)? 

The liboqs License section itself might be simplified then by stating MIT as the baseline license and the intention to not have code licensed incompatible with MIT (e.g., GNU or proprietary) to be included -- and then remove all line items presently listed: That should stop 'unwelcome' contributions and maybe motivate keen observers to notify us of such 'incompatibilities' without us having to take responsibility for documenting (again) which license rules which algorithm.

To your questions: 
- I like provenance information (as perfectly exemplified for LEDA: exact version, immediate upstream repo and ultimate upstream repo), so I'd vote to keep this -- and possibly extend it for all algorithms (e.g., we presently have PQClean Kyber which is not the ultimate upstream for Kyber).
- I agree, reference to 'master' (and programming language) can be removed
- For possible optimisations, I'd refer to the `oqsconfig.h` file to keep documentation up-to-date as code evolves: something along these lines maybe: 

> When optimised versions of the algorithm(s) are available this is documented by processor-specific extensions to the `oqsconfig.h` #defines generated during build. 

In addition, I wonder whether it needs the 'added to liboqs by' section.

Also, repeating myself, I'd suggest to remove the explicit 'License' line item and rather augment the line item "Author's website" with "Author's website and license information: " [Link]. Together with the suggested [README.md#license](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs#license) simplification suggested above, this should deal with license 'review' once and for all.

issue.title: pushing to TARGETNAME
issue.body: Please run this under your account to see that it works. I have (submitted) a private CircleCI account issue that stops me from setting the new environment variable and running this successfully.

comment.body:
I ran locally:
```
docker tag oqs-httpd-img openquantumsafe/httpd-generic
docker push openquantumsafe/httpd-generic
```
and was told that all the layers already exist, which I take to mean that it matched them up with the image I pushed yesterday.

issue.title: Increase max size for signatures in speed.c
issue.body:
Increases max signature sizes for speed tests to 35000 (enough for picnicl1fs). Test code is hard to read, but it uses the last value of `lengths_list` array to allocate the signature buffer in the OQS tests. We'll need to update this value as we add algs with larger sigs.

Fixes issue #159.

comment.body:
> do_openssl-speed.sh redone anyway.

Currently Github is recording a conflict with do\_openssl-speed.sh.  Will someone be rebasing to resolve the conflict before merging?

Fixes issue #159.

comment.body: Easiest in my eyes would be probably for @christianpaquin to just remove `do_openssl-speed.sh` completely from the PR (which I didn't suitably express in my obviously overly short comment above). Sorry for asking for this change in the first place (as it became unnecessary due to the testing overhaul).

issue.title: Move external qtesla folders into a common external one
issue.body: Also removed SPDX statement from external qtesla files.

comment.body:
@xvzcf, I modified the qtesla directory and the CMakeList file, and I get a build error I don't understand. Can you look at the error and my changes to that file to see if I did something wrong?

```
FAILED: src/sig/qtesla/CMakeFiles/qtesla.dir/sig_qtesla.c.o
/usr/bin/cc -D_AMD64_ -Dexternal/portable -Iinclude -I../src/sig/qtesla/external -fPIC -fvisibility=hidden   -Werror -Wall -Wextra -Wpedantic -Wstrict-prototypes -Wshadow -Wformat=2 -Wfloat-equal -Wwrite-strings -O3 -fomit-frame-pointer -fdata-sections -ffunction-sections -Wl,--gc-sections -std=gnu11 -MD -MT src/sig/qtesla/CMakeFiles/qtesla.dir/sig_qtesla.c.o -MF src/sig/qtesla/CMakeFiles/qtesla.dir/sig_qtesla.c.o.d -o src/sig/qtesla/CMakeFiles/qtesla.dir/sig_qtesla.c.o   -c ../src/sig/qtesla/sig_qtesla.c
<command-line>:0:9: error: ISO C99 requires whitespace after the macro name [-Werror]
cc1: all warnings being treated as errors
```

issue.title: Increase max size for signatures in speed.c
issue.body:
Increases max signature sizes for speed tests to 35000 (enough for picnicl1fs). Test code is hard to read, but it uses the last value of `lengths_list` array to allocate the signature buffer in the OQS tests. We'll need to update this value as we add algs with larger sigs.

Fixes issue #159.

issue.title: Check algorithm datasheets
issue.body:
Before the release we should check the algorithm datasheets to make sure they are up to date.  Before doing that, we should identify which things merit manual checking.  We don't have a specification of what things should be present in the file.  So I'm looking for some discussion in this issue about what to include.

- What is the difference between 'source of implementation' and 'implementation version' -- do we need both or is one sufficient?
- Check that the license is indeed correct.
- Probably don't need a language field, everything is C or C + assembly.
- 'Architectures supported in liboqs master branch' should be updated:
  - The language 'liboqs master branch' is old (to back when we also had nist-branch) and should be removed
  - This should be where we report what types of optimizations etc can be built (avx2, bmi, etc.).  What is the best way to word and structure that?

Seeking feedback from @baentsch @christianpaquin @xvzcf @vsoftco

comment.body:
It has always been hard to keep these files in sync with the implementation. I'm not sure they were ever useful in isolation. Perhaps we should consider creating a spreadsheet (in docs/ or on the wiki), with all the KEM/sig in one table; might be more useful to compare the primitives.

The kem/sig code files have a implementation version and contain the primitive sizes. It would be nice to have a test to make sure they match (future work... let's not slow down this release with yet another task...) Perhaps also check the license with the new SPDX macro (although external folders do not contain this info...)

> * What is the difference between 'source of implementation' and 'implementation version' -- do we need both or is one sufficient?

I'd say just keep implementation version.

> * Probably don't need a language field, everything is C or C + assembly.

Agreed.
 
>   * The language 'liboqs master branch' is old (to back when we also had nist-branch) and should be removed

Agreed.
